and the Future of Jobs for Young People"],"prefix":"10.2139","author":[{"given":"Hammad","family":"Ahmed","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]}],"member":"78","deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,12,13]],"date-time":"2025-12-13T08:57:13Z","timestamp":1765616233000},"score":18.6836,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.ssrn.com\/abstract=5833683"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2025]]},"references-count":0,"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.2139\/ssrn.5833683","published":{"date-parts":[[2025]]},"subtype":"preprint"},{"institution":[{"name":"American Economic Association","acronym":["AEARCT"]}],"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,11,21]],"date-time":"2025-11-21T03:16:07Z","timestamp":1763694967056,"version":"3.45.0"},"description":"This project explores whether a digital persuasion approach can shift entrenched gender and masculinity norms in India. Partnering with Karya  an organization that provides digital employment to economically disadvantaged communities across India  this study randomly assigns workers to read, transcribe, and annotate content designed either to subtly challenge traditional gender norms or remain gender neutral. By leveraging insights from social psychology, including motivated reasoning and subliminal priming, I investigate if implicit cues, rather than explicit messages, can more effectively unravel rigid patriarchal norms among adults. This randomized field experiment uniquely applies persuasion through AI-generated content, aiming to reveal mechanisms by which routine tasks can influence deeply held attitudes without resistance. Given Indias entrenched gender disparities in economic, social, and political spheres, this study offers evidence leveraging a scalable, light-touch approach toward reshaping gender norms.","reference-count":0,"publisher":"American Economic Association","content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"DOI":"10.1257\/rct.16061","type":"dataset","created":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]],"date-time":"2025-05-21T16:13:54Z","timestamp":1747844034000},"source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["Jobs of the Future and Gender Norms in India"],"prefix":"10.1257","author":[{"given":"Aditi","family":"Bhowmick","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]}],"member":"11","content-created":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]},"container-title":["AEA Randomized Controlled Trials"],"deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]],"date-time":"2025-05-21T16:13:54Z","timestamp":1747844034000},"score":18.037016,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.aeaweb.org\/doi\/10.1257\/rct.16061"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]},"references-count":0,"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1257\/rct.16061","published":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]}},{"institution":[{"name":"American Economic Association","acronym":["AEARCT"]}],"indexed":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,22]],"date-time":"2025-05-22T04:40:53Z","timestamp":1747888853187,"version":"3.41.0"},"description":"This project explores whether a digital persuasion approach can shift entrenched gender and masculinity norms in India. Partnering with Karya  an organization that provides digital employment to economically disadvantaged communities across India  this study randomly assigns workers to read, transcribe, and annotate content designed either to subtly challenge traditional gender norms or remain gender neutral. By leveraging insights from social psychology, including motivated reasoning and subliminal priming, I investigate if implicit cues, rather than explicit messages, can more effectively unravel rigid patriarchal norms among adults. This randomized field experiment uniquely applies persuasion through AI-generated content, aiming to reveal mechanisms by which routine tasks can influence deeply held attitudes without resistance. Given Indias entrenched gender disparities in economic, social, and political spheres, this study offers evidence leveraging a scalable, light-touch approach toward reshaping gender norms.","reference-count":0,"publisher":"American Economic Association","content-domain":{"domain":[],"crossmark-restriction":false},"DOI":"10.1257\/rct.16061-1.0","type":"dataset","created":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]],"date-time":"2025-05-21T20:13:54Z","timestamp":1747858434000},"source":"Crossref","is-referenced-by-count":0,"title":["Jobs of the Future and Gender Norms in India"],"prefix":"10.1257","author":[{"given":"Aditi","family":"Bhowmick","sequence":"first","affiliation":[]}],"member":"11","content-created":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]},"container-title":["AEA Randomized Controlled Trials"],"deposited":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]],"date-time":"2025-05-21T20:13:54Z","timestamp":1747858434000},"score":17.961758,"resource":{"primary":{"URL":"https:\/\/www.aeaweb.org\/doi\/10.1257\/rct.16061-1.0"}},"issued":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]},"references-count":0,"URL":"https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1257\/rct.16061-1.0","relation":{"is-version-of":[{"id-type":"doi","id":"10.1257\/rct.16061","asserted-by":"subject"}]},"published":{"date-parts":[[2025,5,21]]}}],"items-per-page":5,"query":{"start-index":0,"search-terms":null}}}
